-Sin duda, otra obra maestra de Valve. Donde el paso del tiempo (ya con 12 a√±os) casi no le afectaron, envejeciendo muy bien al d√≠a de hoy. Lo que mas llama la atenci√≥n, que a pesar de ser un juego totalmente diferente y con otra ambientaci√≥n, los echos trascurran en el mismo universo que el de Half life. 
-El juego trata basicamente sobre una serie de puzzle  que deben ser resueltos teletransportando al personaje y objetos simples usando el "Arma de portales", un dispositivo que puede crear portales interespaciales entre dos superficies planas.  Chell la protagonista , es desafiada por llamada GLaDOS (Una I.A ) para completar cada desafi√≥.  La trama se llevara acabo en las instalaciones de "Aperture Science" , la contra parte de "Black mesa" .
-A pesar que su campa√±a principal es algo corta, su ingeniosa jugabilidad te invitan a continuar con los desaf√≠os extras . Tambi√©n podremos descargar mapas Workshop creado por fan√°ticos.

Portal 2 is better in almost every way, but every great game series has to start somewhere!
A great game everyone should play.

While I recommend the game (it's a brilliant concept) I think most players will find it disappointingly short. I am endowed with average intelligence yet I managed to finish it in 5-6 hours including the bonus chambers, and some people can do it in two. I recommend skipping it and going straight to Portal 2, which is longer, much more varied, and offers more toys to play with.
Even a decade later it's still a great game. Though it is a little bit short, I still liked it.

super geiles spiel

Portal is a perfect little pearl of a game.  I went back to it again for the first time after playing Portal 2 (which seemed to me at first to be bigger and better in every way) but really they‚Äôre just different; each is good in their own way.  The biggest difference is their tone: Portal is cold and mysterious.  We get this impression both from the visuals (test chambers are much more sterile and bleak than they are in the sequel) and from GLaDOS, the only ‚Äòcharacter‚Äô in the game, who, in contrast to Portal 2, is less of a dry comic relief element and is more sinister and enigmatic, a presence whose only moments of humour come from her hopeless ignorance of human nature. Compare this to the GLaDOS of Portal 2, who is far more sarcastic and self-aware: more human and less computer.  

	Also, the first Portal is far more compressed than its sequel.  It‚Äôs just as long as it needs to be, there‚Äôs no fluff here; all its fat has been trimmed out, and it‚Äôs all the better for it.  Portal 2 is of course longer, funnier, more light-hearted, and contains more characters than its predecessor.  I think Valve were right to change the tone in Portal 2.  The first game was so perfect and had explored everything it needed to explore, a big change was absolutely necessary.  I could never say that one is better than the other.  I think both games have their merits.

	Finally, I just want to gush about my favourite part of Portal.  There are mild spoilers here so you might want to play the game first before reading (but really who hasn‚Äôt played Portal at this point? If you haven‚Äôt, hurry up and buy it!).

	My favourite part of the game has to be near the end, after completing the ‚Äòlast‚Äô chamber.  Up until this point everything has been so regimented, so orderly: you settle into the feeling the test chambers give you, you‚Äôve become used to the rhyme of using whatever tools you are given to open the exit door of the test chamber to get to the elevator, and then it‚Äôs on to the next chamber.  Then all of a sudden GLaDOS tries to dispose of you, you escape her clutches, and this replicated pattern you have grown used to is ripped away from you.  You step ‚Äòoutside‚Äô the chambers, and you feel that you‚Äôre somewhere you‚Äôre not supposed to be (even GLaDOS tells you as much), and that‚Äôs exhilarating.  It starts feeling less of a puzzle game with clearly delineated levels and more like an exploration adventure with puzzle elements.  It‚Äôs just genius.

	The writer Neil Gaiman says that great fiction is taking the reader by the hand, promising them that you will never let go of that hand, leading them into a room pitch black with darkness, and then letting go of that hand.  This is exactly what Portal does so well.
This game is fun and one of the best games I have I recommend this game if you like puzzle/adventure type games since this game is both.

Portal is quite a game. It has good mechanics and it has a good premise, but it is too short. Way too short. There are only 18 test chambers then the ending sequence then boom the game is over. Portal has the ability to be as good a game as Portal 2, but instead it's just a tech demo. It's lucky it's a good tech demo, because if it wasn't, I wouldn't recommend it.

[h1] There are Portals in the game.......[/h1]

I thought about writing a big paragraph but I don't think anyone would be interested in reading it. Portal just might be the best puzzle game out there. Sure, I might be very wrong since I've not played that many puzzle games. I'm terribly sorry if I've said some total nonsense bs. I'm not a big fan of puzzle games. The Gameplay is one of the most unique I've seen in years. At first glance it seems like a generic first-person shooter but boy I was wrong.

The gameplay is nothing like I imagined it would be. I thought I would be blowing some stuff but it was a puzzle game. I'll be honest, it took some time to get used to this type of game and the only reason I've even played this is because it was developed and published by Valve which is a bit sad thing to confess. 

You have to credit Valve for coming up with an idea to combine first person game with puzzle solving as the main focus. I'm really impressed. The graphics and the level of detail are fantastic considering Portal is a 12 year old game. Optimization is perfect, I can assure you this will work on all potato PCs.
Do I like this game? Of course I love it!! And I, recommend it because...
[b]its Portal[/b]
If you're bored, you know exactly what to do now......

Humour (mostly dry, with a side of slapstick) (gets dark by implication)
Puzzle and problem solving (if you don't, then maybe avoid)
Cute boxes
Defying the so-called laws of physics

This is one of my favorite games, period.

The atmosphere built by desolation, ambiance, and the omnipresent AI GLaDOS is something I have yet to experience in any other game. Not even Portal 2 was able to recapture that atmosphere.

All the major turning points in the game are perfectly executed.
And with the addition of the ARG update that added the SSTV signal and morse code producing radios makes it that much more unsettling.
